  • Method Details

    • subtract

      public double subtract(double diffX1, double diffY1, double diffX2, double diffY2)
      calculates the difference of angles between pairs of points in set1 and set 2 ( angle of (diffX1, diffY1) - angle of (diffX2, diffY2). diffX1, diffX2 are the difference in x and y between 2 points in set 1, and diffX2, diffY2 are the difference for the same matched point pair in set2. The reference frame is polar clockwise. For example, (diffX1, diffY1) being (1, 4) and (diffX2, diffY2) being (3.536, 2.12) leads to angles 284 minus 329 = -45. Note that to transform (diffX1, diffY1) to (diffX2, diffY2) one would apply -1*result of this method. 
             clockwise -->
              +Y        V
              270
           III | IV
       180 --------- 0   +X
           II  |  I
               90
      Note that the subtraction is from closest angles. For example, if point 1 is in qI and point 2 is in qIV, 360 is added to point 1's angle, then the equation is (2*PI + point1 angle) - (point 2 angle).
      Parameters:
      diffX1 -
      diffY1 -
      diffX2 -
      diffY2 -
      Returns:

    • polarAngleCCW

      public static double polarAngleCCW(double x, double y)
      calculates the polar theta in radians given x and y w.r.t. origin. theta increases in value in a counter clockwise direction (CCW). range of returned values is 0 to 2*pi.
      Parameters:
      x -
      y -
      Returns:
      angle in range [0, 2*Math.PI)

    • polarAngleCW

      public static double polarAngleCW(double x, double y)
      calculates the polar theta in radians given x and y w.r.t. origin. theta increases in value in a clockwise direction (CW).
      Parameters:
      x -
      y -
      Returns:
      polar angle in radians

    • calcAngleAddition

      public static double calcAngleAddition(double theta1, double theta2, boolean useRadians)
      given twoPi in degrees or in radians, return the angle sum corrected to the larger angle frame, e.g. 0 + 350 = 710.
      Parameters:
      theta1 -
      theta2 -
      useRadians -
      Returns:

    • calcAngleAddition

      public static double calcAngleAddition(double theta1, double theta2, boolean useRadians, double[] outputQuadrantCorrected)
      given angles in degrees or in radians, return the angle sum corrected to the larger angle frame, e.g. 0 + 350 = 710. It always chooses the smallest difference in quadrant space between the two angles (adding a cycle if needed) before adding.
      Parameters:
      theta1 -
      theta2 -
      useRadians -
      outputQuadrantCorrected - quadrant corrected values of [rotationInDegrees0, rotationInDegrees1]
      Returns:

    • getAngleAverageInDegrees

      protected static double getAngleAverageInDegrees(double rotationInDegrees0, double rotationInDegrees1, double[] outputQuadrantCorrected)
      calculate the angular average of rotDegrees0 and rotDegrees1 with corrections for quadrants if necessary. For example, 0 averaged with 350 is 355. Any changes in the given angles for quadrant math are seen in the populated outputQuadrantCorrected.
      Parameters:
      outputQuadrantCorrected - quadrant corrected values of [rotationInDegrees0, rotationInDegrees1]
      Returns:

    • calculateAverageWithQuadrantCorrections

      public static double calculateAverageWithQuadrantCorrections(double[] angles, boolean useRadians)
      calculate the average of the angles using quadrant corrections (note, angles is modified by descending sort). Runtime complexity is O(N*lg2N) for sort plus O(N). Note, may change to use CountingSort for N > 80 and max(angles) ~ 360 in the future.
      Parameters:
      angles - angles in units of degrees. Note that this array is modified by use here so pass a copy if it should not be.
      useRadians -
      Returns:

    • correctForQuadrants

      public static void correctForQuadrants(List<Double> thetas, boolean useRadians)
      Runtime complexity is O(N*lg2N) for sort plus O(N). Note, may change to use CountingSort for N > 80 and max(angles) ~ 360 in the future.
